text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 8.7.18, Return Preparer Misconduct Cases.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
Incorporates Appeals Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-0616-0003, Requesting Examination Assistance on Docketed Cases, issued on June 24, 2016, effective on August 29, 2016.

Misconduct Cases

) Unscrupulous return preparers may alter the taxpayer tax data (e.g. false dependents, expenses, deductions, credits, income) and/or misdirect portion or all of the refund. The issue of RPM may arise through taxpayer initiated contact (for example, Toll-Free, Field Assistance, Taxpayer Service) or through IRS enforcement investigative processes (e.g. Agent or Tax Compliance Officer contact, Automated Underreporter dence, campus examination correspondence, Revenue Officer contact, Criminal Investigation inquiries). (
) Taxpayers who claim to be a victim of return preparer misconduct may a complaint and the required documentation to the IRS to request and relief. (
) Refer to IRM
, Return Preparer Misconduct Victim Assistance ized Accounts Management Processing, for more information. (

) An open complaint with the Identity Theft Victim Assistance will be with an Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) control with either Identity Theft Victim Assistance - Accounts Management (IDTVA-A) or Identity Theft Victim Assistance - Compliance (IDTVA-C). (
) Fully allowed or partially allowed complaints will be noted on IDRS with a Transaction Code
AC
with a RPM category code of RPM
, RPM
or RPM
) The Service’s policy statement to assist victims of RPM can be found at
, Policy Statement
) Additional information can be found at http://appeals.web.irs.gov/tech_ services/rpm/default.htm. (

) Return preparer misconduct generally involves the orchestrated and ﬁling of false income tax returns (in either paper or electronic form) by preparers who may claim: a. Inﬂated personal or business expenses; b. False deductions; c. Unallowable credits; d. Excessive exemptions; or e. Fraudulent tax credits such as the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC). (
) RPM may also involve a return preparer who misdirects the refund to the return preparer’s account. (
) The preparer’s clients may or may not have knowledge of the false deductions, exemptions, and/or credits shown on their tax returns. Example: A taxpayer used a preparer in
to prepare and ﬁle Form
preparer changed the return by increasing the withholding tax and diverted the excess refund into the preparer’s personal account.
Fully allowed or partially allowed complaints will be noted on IDRS with a Transaction Code 971 AC 504 with a RPM category code of RPM1,
The preparer’s clients may or may not have knowledge of the false expenses, deductions, exemptions, and/or credits shown on their tax returns.

Example: A taxpayer used a preparer in 2013 to prepare and ﬁle Form 1040. The preparer changed the return by increasing the withholding tax claimed and diverted the excess refund into the preparer’s personal account.
Signing Preparer - Preparer information appears on the processed tax return.
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines

Note: An individual who prepares federal tax returns for compensation is to have a Preparer Tax Identiﬁcation Number (PTIN) issued by IRS and enter it on every tax return prepared for compensation along with the er’s name and signature. Any preparer with a PTIN is in the business of preparing tax returns or has held themselves out as in the business of preparing tax returns. (

) Ghost Preparer / Non-Signing Preparer - No preparer information appears the processed tax return but the return was not self prepared (for purposes this guidance only). Note: An individual who fails to identify themselves as a paid preparer on the return is considered a ghost preparer. There is no SSN, PTIN, EIN, or identifying number accompanying the return to identify the return preparer. Note: The deﬁnitions in (
) and (
) above are for the purposes of this guidance only. (
) RPM Complaint - Taxpayers alleging preparer misconduct are generally required to provide Form
- A, Tax Return Preparer Fraud or Affidavit, signed under penalties of perjury and Form
, Return Complaint, along with additional required documentation to support their gations. Refer to IRM
for general documentation requirements. (
) Complete Complaint - All required documentation is provided and the information is considered veriﬁed and valid. (

) Acceptance of Complaint - Acceptance of an RPM complaint is dependent upon the receipt of required documentation, veriﬁcation of the preparer and facts and circumstances of each complaint gathered from the taxpayer’s mentation and account research. When a complaint is accepted, the IRS will determine the type of relief to which the taxpayer is entitled. (
) Actual Return or Return as Intended to be Filed - Taxpayer’s tax return submitted with the RPM complaint reﬂecting the return unaltered by the preparer and as intended to be ﬁled. (
) Relief / Resolution - The actions that the IRS will take on account, which are dependent on the category of the misconduct discussed in IRM

relief granted by the IRS generally takes one of the following forms: • Taxpayer’s actual return (return as intended to be ﬁled) is accepted as return of record and account is adjusted to reﬂect that return. • Removal of the preparer portion of the refund attributable to preparer conduct using General Ledger (GL) account. • Issuance of an additional refund plus interest as required by law. (

) Taxpayer Portion of a Refund - Any portion of the refund received or deter- mined to be received by the taxpayer or any portion of the refund where the taxpayer received beneﬁt (e.g. Refund offset to legitimate liability including BFS offsets). (
) Preparer Portion of a Refund - Portion of the refund resulting from the data on the processed tax return or portion of the refund misdirected to the preparer. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
G

Note: An individual who fails to identify themselves as a paid preparer on the tax return is considered a ghost preparer. There is no SSN, PTIN, EIN, or identifying number accompanying the return to identify the return preparer.
Preparer Portion of a Refund - Portion of the refund resulting from the altered data on the processed tax return or portion of the refund misdirected to the
Preparer Misconduct Cases 8.7.18
) RPM complaints have been categorized into four (
) basic fact patterns. (
) Within each of the

categories, different procedures may apply depending Categories upon the speciﬁc facts and circumstances, such as whether there is a preparer or a non-signing preparer (ghost), and/or the method of refund issuance (e.g., refund anticipation check (RAC), split refund, paper check). (

) These facts and circumstances determine the speciﬁc documentation ments for each category. Veriﬁcation requirements and account information determine the treatment stream and whether the taxpayer is entitled to a refund or a portion of the refund misdirected by the preparer. (
) An unauthorized ﬁling may occur when a taxpayer was in contact with a preparer and did not sign or authorize the ﬁling of a return, but a return was
Unauthorized ﬁled with the taxpayer’s name and taxpayer identifying number. (
) The IRS may administratively adjust the taxpayer’s account to reﬂect the return as intended and remove the portion of the refund attributable to misconduct. (
) Taxpayer may receive a refund for the amount reﬂected on the actual return intended that was not received. (
) Refer to IRM
, Identifying RPM Category, for more information examples. (
) An altered return may occur when a taxpayer was in contact with a and did authorize a return ﬁling, but states tax data (exemptions, income,

Authorized expenses, deductions, credits, etc.) on his/her return was altered before it Altered Return ﬁled or the return otherwise includes items which the taxpayer did not and No authorize. Refund Due (
) The IRS may administratively adjust the taxpayer’s account to reﬂect the Taxpayer payer’s actual return and remove the portion of the refund attributable to preparer misconduct. (
) If the taxpayer is in a balance due situation after processing the actual the taxpayer is liable for the amount owed. The taxpayer is not, however, for the preparer portion of a refund. (
) Refer to IRM
, Identifying RPM Category, for more information examples. (
) An altered return may occur when a taxpayer was in contact with a and authorized a return ﬁling, but the tax data (exemptions, income,

Authorized deductions, credits, etc.) on the return was altered before it was ﬁled or the Altered Return return includes items which the taxpayer did not authorize and the taxpayer and the seeking another refund. is Requesting (

) The IRS may administratively adjust the taxpayer’s account to reﬂect the Refund payer’s actual return and remove the portion of the refund attributable to preparer misconduct and the taxpayer may receive a refund for the amount the refund from his/her actual return that was not received.

) Internal Revenue Manual
The IRS may administratively adjust the taxpayer’s account to reﬂect the actual return as intended and remove the portion of the refund attributable to preparer
Technical and Procedural (
) Refer to IRM
, Identifying RPM Category, for more information examples. (

) A misdirected refund may occur when a taxpayer was in contact with a preparer and did authorize a return ﬁling, but states although no tax data Misdirected altered, the direct deposit information or address was altered diverting all or and portion of the refund to the preparer. (
) The IRS may administratively remove the portion of the refund misdirected the preparer and the taxpayer may receive a refund. (
) Refer to IRM
, Identifying RPM Category, for more information examples. (
) The taxpayer is required to submit documentation to support his/her claim preparer misconduct. (

) Documentation requirements may vary depending upon the category, requested relief, and whether the original return was signed by a preparer considered a ghost preparer. Note: If the speciﬁc category could not be determined based on the information taxpayer provided then reference Category

for requirements if taxpayer not seeking an additional refund. However, if there is indication that the taxpayer is seeking an additional refund or this determination cannot be made then reference Category
requirements. (
) For a full list of acceptable documentation, refer to IRM
, RPM General Documentation Requirements. (
) Incomplete documentation will result in the denial of the complaint by (
) The types of RPM relief is dependent upon the category of the complaint. (
) For Category
cases, refer to IRM
, Category
- Unauthorized Relief Filing, for minimum documentation requirements and relief available. (

cases, refer to IRM

cases, the original ﬁled return be considered a nullity and the new return will be recognized as the original ﬁling. In Category
cases, the altered return is not a nullity.

) When in receipt of a complaint, refer to the sections below for instructions ticular to the work stream. (
) Refer to IRM
, Incomplete Complaints, for IDTVA actions when the taxpayer has not provided all required documentation. (
) Taxpayers are given an opportunity to complete the complaint. If the documentation has not been provided, IDTVA will disallow the complaint. (
) IDTVA will use the procedures in IRM
, Disallowance, when a RPM complaint is disallowed. (
) IDTVA will issue Letter
c when a full disallowance is made on a Category
or
case. For Category
, this category is not a claim for refund and therefore a no consideration Letter

c will be sent by IDVTA. The letters provide the taxpayer with the right to ﬁle suit only. Cases will not be sent to Appeals solely for consideration of incomplete complaints since there are no reasonable cause considerations. Appeals does not have authority to provide victim assistance specialized account processing when IDTVA concludes that RPM is not present. Appeals may still consider the underlying tax issue in cases once IDTVA determines that RPM is not present. Exception: Appeals may see partially disallowed incomplete complaints as explained in the next paragraph. (
) Partial disallowances may arise in Category
, Category
and Category
cases. IDVTA will issue Letter

c when a partial disallowance is made. Appeals may receive a case where the only issue in the disallowance is the disallowance of a refund based on an expired Refund Statute Expiration (RSED). The Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) will need to consider the RSED was still open at the time the complaint was made. (
) Cases that were previously worked and denied by IDTVA will have a TC
with a RC
If this is on the account, the case should not be referred to IDTVA. (
) Taxpayers who later secure documentation to complete their complaint be directed to ﬁle the complaint per the instructions on the Form
-A, Return Preparer Fraud or Misconduct Affidavit, for reconsideration. ATEs will continue to work the underlying tax issue. (

, Taxpayer Raises New Issue. Place Feature Code “RM” on ACDS. (

, Taxpayer Provides New Information. Place Feature Code “RM” on ACDS. Note: If the exception in IRM
) applies, then use the referral in IRM
and retain jurisdiction of the case. Place Feature Code on ACDS and indicate this is a non-docketed case on Form
, Division Feedback Report and Transmittal Memorandum.

Partial disallowances may arise in Category 1, Category 3 and Category 4 cases. IDVTA will issue Letter 106c when a partial disallowance is made. Appeals may receive a case where the only issue in the disallowance is the disallowance of a refund based on an expired Refund Statute Expiration Date (RSED). The Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) will need to consider the RSED was still open at the time the complaint was made.

Note: If the exception in IRM 8.6.1.6.5 (2) applies, then use the referral procedures in IRM 8.7.18.6 and retain jurisdiction of the case. Place Feature Code “RM” on ACDS and indicate this is a non-docketed case on Form 10467, Appeals Division Feedback Report and Transmittal Memorandum.
Technical and Procedural (

) When a taxpayer raises potential ID theft in a ﬁeld sourced case that has been previously considered or provides new information with regards to theft claim in a docketed case, the ATE will follow the Docketed Exam tance procedures in IRM
, Appeals Docketed Cases, Examination Assistance Requests. Place Feature Code “RM” on ACDS. (

) When a taxpayer raises potential RPM or provides new information in a campus sourced docketed case, the ATE will refer it to the Identity Theft Victim Assistance Unit (IDTVA-C) for review and determination. Place Code “RM” on ACDS. (

) The ATE will immediately notify the Counsel Attorney assigned to the case the Associate Area Counsel if an attorney has not been assigned) when it learned that the petitioner is pursuing a complaint for RPM. (
) The ATE will prepare a package to refer to the IDTVA-C mailbox. (
) The package will include: a. Form
, Appeals Division Feedback Report and Transmittal randum, indicating that this is part of a docketed case. b. The Form
, Return Preparer Complaint, submitted by the c. The Form
-A, Tax Return Preparer or Fraud Misconduct submitted by the taxpayer. d. All supporting documentation submitted by the taxpayer. (
) The ATE will forward the package by secure email for review to the ance RPM Liaison at “*W&I IDT:KC:SPEC-EXAM” with read receipt. (
) IDTVA-C will mark these requests as priority and will make every attempt make a determination within
days. (
) If the complaint is denied by IDTVA-C, they will provide the reasons for the decision to the ATE by secure email. (
) If the complaint is approved by IDTVA-C, they will provide the ATE with a detailed description of the relief granted by secure email. Refer to IRM
, Required Account Action, for instructions on adjusting with RPM present. Depending on the category and type of adjustments needed, the ATE will prepare: a. Form
identifying the account adjustments b. Form
to post the TC
AC
for partially and allowed c. Form
to update the Name, Address, or Filing Status (
) When tax computations are necessary, the ATE will have a Tax Specialist (TCS) prepare the Form
and Form
Instructions. (
) The ATE should seek assistance from Counsel in the preparation of the decision document until a template is available on Appeals Generator of and Letters (APGolf). (
) The ATE will resolve the remainder of the case as appropriate using procedures. (

days. (

for incomplete complaints. (
